characters: ED SULLIVAN AND MARILYN MONROE STAND ON STAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A normal Denny's, Spires-like coffee shop in Los Angeles. It's about 9:00 in the morning. While the place isn't jam there's a healthy number of people drinking coffee, munch on bacon and eating eggs. Two of these people are a YOUNG MAN and a YOUNG WOMAN. Th Young Man has a slight working-class English accent and,  like his fellow countryman, smokes cigarettes like they'r going out of style. It is impossible to tell where the Young Woman is from or how old she is; everything she does contradicts something she did. The boy and girl sit in a booth. Their dialogue to be said in a rapid pace "HIS GIRL FRIDAY" fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, forget it, it's too risky. I'm  through doin' that shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that, the same thing  every time: never again, I'm through,  too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that's what I always say. I'm  always right too, but В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– but you forget about it in a day  or two -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– yeah, well, the days of me  forgittin' are over, and the days of  me rememberin' have just begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you go on like this, you know  what you sound like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sound like a sensible fucking man,  is what I sound like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like a duck. (imitates a duck) Quack, quack, quack, quack, quack,  quack, quack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well take heart, 'cause you're never  gonna hafta hear it again. Because  since I'm never gonna do it again,  you're never gonna hafta hear me  quack about how I'm never gonna do  it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy and girl laugh, their laughter putting a pause in there, back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Correct. I got all tonight to quack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS comes by with a pot of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get anybody anymore coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress pours the Young Woman's coffee. The Young Ma lights up another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doin' fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress leaves. The Young Man takes a drag off of hi smoke. The Young Woman pours a ton of cream and sugar into her  coffee. The Young Man goes right back into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the way it is now, you're  takin' the same fuckin' risk as when  you rob a bank. You take more of a  risk. Banks are easier!  Federal  banks aren't supposed to stop you  anyway, during a robbery. They're  insured, why should they care? You  don't even need a gun in a federal  bank. I heard about this guy, walked  into a federal bank with a portable  phone, handed the phone to the teller,  the guy on the other end of the phone  said: "We got this guy's little girl,  and if you don't give him all your  money, we're gonna kill 'er."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A it worked, that's what I'm  talkin' about! Knucklehead walks in  a bank with a telephone, not a pistol,  not a shotgun, but a fuckin' phone,  cleans the place out, and they don't  lift a fuckin' finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they hurt the little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. There probably never  was a little girl В– the point of the  story isn't the little girl. The  point of the story is they robbed  the bank with a telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna rob banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sayin' I wanna rob banks,  I'm just illustrating that if we  did, it would be easier than what we  been doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't want to be a bank robber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, all those guys are goin' down  the same road, either dead or servin'  twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no more liquor stores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have we been talking about?  Yeah, no more-liquor-stores. Besides,  it ain't the giggle it usta be. Too  many foreigners own liquor stores.  Vietnamese, Koreans, they can't  fuckin' speak English. You tell 'em:  "Empty out the register," and they  don't know what it fuckin' means.  They make it too personal. We keep  on, one of those gook motherfuckers'  gonna make us kill 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna kill anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna kill anybody either.  But they'll probably put us in a  situation where it's us of them. And  if it's not the gooks, it these old  Jews who've owned the store for  fifteen fuckin' generations. Ya got  Grandpa Irving sittin' behind the  counter with a fuckin' Magnum. Try  walkin' into one of those stores  with nothin' but a telephone, see  how far it gets you. Fuck it, forget  it, we're out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what else is there, day jobs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Not this life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calls to the Waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garcon! Coffee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then looks to his girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waitress comes by, pouring him some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snotty) "Garcon" means boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She splits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here? It's a coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that? People never  rob restaurants, why not? Bars, liquor  stores, gas stations, you get your  head blown off stickin' up one of  them. Restaurants, on the other hand,  you catch with their pants down.  They're not expecting to get robbed,  or not as expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking to idea) I bet in places like this you could  cut down on the hero factor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct. Just like banks, these places  are insured. The managers don't give  a fuck, they're just tryin' to get  ya out the door before you start  pluggin' diners.  Waitresses, forget  it, they ain't takin' a bullet for  the register. Busboys, some wetback  gettin' paid a dollar fifty a hour  gonna really give a fuck you're  stealin' from the owner. Customers  are sittin' there with food in their  mouths, they don't know what's goin'  on. One minute they're havin' a Denver  omelet, next minute somebody's  stickin' a gun in their face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Woman visibly takes in the idea. The Young Man  continues in a low voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I got the idea last liquor store  we stuck up. 'Member all those  customers kept comin' in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you got the idea to take  everybody's wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We made more from the wallets then  we did the register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people go to restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of wallets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty smart, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Woman scans the restaurant with this new  information. She sees all the PATRONS eating, lost in conversations. T tired WAITRESS, taking orders. The BUSBOYS going through motions, collecting dishes. The MANAGER complaining to th COOK about something. A smiles breaks out on the Young Wo face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty smart. (into it) I'm ready, let's go, right here,  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, same as before, you're  crowd control, I handle the employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both take out their .32-caliber pistols and lay them the table. He looks at her and she back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Pumpkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Honey Bunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Pumpkin and Honey Bunny grab their weapons stand up and rob the restaurant. Pumpkin's robbery person is that of the in-control professional. Honey Bunny's is  that of the psychopathic, hair-triggered, loose cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to all) Everybody be cool this is a robbery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of you fuckin' pricks move and  I'll execute every one of you  motherfuckers!  Got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old gas guzzling, dirty, white 1974 Chevy Nova BARRELS down a homeless-ridden street in Hollywood. In the front  seat are two young fellas В– one white, one black В– both wearing cheap black suits with thin black ties under long green dusters. Their names are VINCENT VEGA (white) and J WINNFIELD (black). Jules is behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– Okay now, tell me about the hash  bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What so you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hash is legal there, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's legal, but is ain't a  hundred percent legal. I mean you  can't walk into a restaurant, roll a  joint, and start puffin' away. You're  only supposed to smoke in your home  or certain designated places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are hash bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it breaks down like this: it's  legal to buy it, it's legal to own  it and, if you're the proprietor of  a hash bar, it's legal to sell it.  It's legal to carry it, which doesn't  really matter 'cause В– get a load of  this В– if the cops stop you, it's  illegal for this to search you.  Searching you is a right that the  cops in Amsterdam don't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That did it, man В– I'm fuckin' goin',  that's all there is to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll dig it the most. But you know  what the funniest thing about Europe  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the little differences. A lotta  the same shit we got here, they got  there, but there they're a little  different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Examples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in Amsterdam, you can buy beer  in a movie theatre. And I don't mean  in a paper cup either. They give you  a glass of beer, like in a bar. In  Paris, you can buy beer at  MacDonald's. Also, you know what  they call a Quarter Pounder with  Cheese in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't call it a Quarter Pounder  with Cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they got the metric system there,  they wouldn't know what the fuck a  Quarter Pounder is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they call it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royale with Cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) Royale with Cheese. What'd they call  a Big Mac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Mac's a Big Mac, but they call  it Le Big Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le Big Mac. What do they call a  Whopper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, I didn't go into a Burger  King.  But you know what they put on  french fries in Holland instead of  ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayonnaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen 'em do it. And I don't mean a  little bit on the side of the plate,  they fuckin' drown 'em in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uuccch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk of the Chevy OPENS UP, Jules and Vincent reach  inside, taking out two .45 Automatics, loading and cockin them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have shotguns for this  kind of deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Counting our guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there could be five guys up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have fuckin' shotguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They CLOSE the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Jules, their long matching overcoats practica dragging on the ground, walk through the courtyard of wha looks like a hacienda-style Hollywood apartment building. We TRACK alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did Marsellus and her meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, however people meet people.  She usta be an actress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ever do anything I woulda saw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think her biggest deal was she  starred in a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a pilot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know the shows on TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but you're aware that there's  an invention called television, and  on that invention they show shows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way they pick the shows on  TV is they make one show, and that  show's called a pilot. And they show  that one show to the people who pick  the shows, and on the strength of  that one show, they decide if they  want to make more shows. Some get  accepted and become TV programs, and  some don't, and become nothing. She  starred in one of the ones that became  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Jules walk through the reception area and wai for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Antwan Rockamora? Half- black, half-Samoan, usta call him  Tony Rocky Horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah maybe, fat right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go so far as to call the  brother fat. He's got a weight  problem.  What's the nigger gonna  do, he's Samoan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know who you mean, what  about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Marsellus fucked his ass up  good.  And word around the campfire,  it was on account of Marsellus  Wallace's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator arrives, the men step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he do, fuck her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no no no no no, nothin' that  bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave her a foot massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foot massage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules nods his head: "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules nods his head: "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Marsellus do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sent a couple of guys over to his  place.  They took him out on the  patio of his apartment, threw his  ass over the balcony.  Nigger fell  four stories. They had this garden  at the bottom, enclosed in glass,  like one of them greenhouses В– nigger  fell through that. Since then, he's  kinda developed a speech impediment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open, Jules and Vincent exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a damn shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEADICAM in front of Jules and Vincent as they make a be down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still I hafta say, play with matches,  ya get burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't be givin' Marsellus  Wallace's new bride a foot massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think he overreacted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Antwan probably didn't expect  Marsellus to react like he did, but  he had to expect a reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a foot massage, a foot massage  is nothing, I give my mother a foot  massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's laying hands on Marsellus  Wallace's new wife in a familiar  way. Is it as bad as eatin' her out  В– no, but you're in the same fuckin'  ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules stops Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa... whoa... whoa... stop right  there.  Eatin' a bitch out, and givin'  a bitch a foot massage ain't even  the same fuckin' thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the same thing, the same ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't no ballpark either. Look  maybe your method of massage differs  from mine, but touchin' his lady's  feet, and stickin' your tongue in  her holyiest of holyies, ain't the  same ballpark, ain't the same league,  ain't even the same fuckin' sport. Foot massages don't mean shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever given a foot massage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be tellin' me about foot  massages В– I'm the foot fuckin'  master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given a lot of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit yeah. I got my technique down  man, I don't tickle or nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever given a guy a foot  massage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules looks at him a long moment В– he's been set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts walking down the hall.  Vincent, smiling, walks little bit behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you give me a foot massage В–  I'm kinda tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you best back off, I'm gittin'  pissed В– this is the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stand in front of the door numbered "49." The whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Seven-twenty-two in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't quite time, let's hang back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move a little away from the door, facing each other, still whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, just because I wouldn't give  no man a foot massage, don't make it  right for Marsellus to throw Antwan  off a building into a glass- motherfuckin-house, fuckin' up the  way the nigger talks. That ain't  right, man. Motherfucker do that to  me, he better paralyze my ass, 'cause  I'd kill'a motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sayin' he was right, but  you're sayin' a foot massage don't  mean nothing, and I'm sayin' it does.  I've given a million ladies a million  foot massages and they all meant  somethin'. We act like they don't,  but they do. That's what's so fuckin'  cool about 'em. This sensual thing's  goin' on that nobody's talkin about,  but you know it and she knows it,  fuckin' Marsellus knew it, and Antwan  shoulda known fuckin' better. That's  his fuckin' wife, man. He ain't gonna  have a sense of humor about that  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an interesting point, but  let's get into character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia. Why you so interested in big  man's wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Marsellus is leavin' for Florida  and when he's gone, he wants me to  take care of Mia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making a gun out of his finger and placing it to his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that! Take her out. Show her a  good time. Don't let her get lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be takin' Mia Wallace  out on a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't a date. It's like when you  and your buddy's wife go to a movie  or somethin'. It's just... you know...  good company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE YOUNG GUYS, obviously in over their heads, sit at a table with hamburgers, french fries and soda pops laid ou One of them flips the LOUD BOLT on the door, opening it t REVEAL Jules and Vincent in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men stroll inside. The three young caught-off-guard Guys are: MARVIN, the black young man, who open the door, will, as scene progresses, back into the corner. ROGER, a young blond-haired surfer kid with a "Flock of  Seagulls" haircut, who has yet to say a word, sits at the table with a big sloppy hamburger in his hand. BRETT, a white, preppy-looking sort with a blow-dry hairc Vincent and Jules take in the place, with their hands in  their pockets. Jules is the one who does the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you boys doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brett) Am I trippin', or did I just ask you  a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doin' okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jules and Brett talk, Vincent moves behind the young G

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who we are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brett shakes his head: "No."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're associates of your business  partner Marsellus Wallace, you  remember your business partner  dont'ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brett) Now I'm gonna take a wild guess here:  you're Brett, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Brett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. Well, you remember  your business partner Marsellus  Wallace, dont'ya Brett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you. Looks like me and  Vincent caught you at breakfast,  sorry 'bout that.  What'cha eatin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamburgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamburgers. The cornerstone of any  nutritious breakfast. What kinda  hamburgers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheeseburgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean where did you get'em? MacDonald's, Wendy's, Jack-in-the- Box, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Kahuna Burger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Kahuna Burger. That's that  Hawaiian burger joint. I heard they  got some tasty burgers. I ain't never  had one myself, how are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I try one of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours is this one, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules grabs the burger and take a bite of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uuummmm, that's a tasty burger. (to Vincent) Vince, you ever try a Big Kahuna  Burger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jules holds out the Big Kahuna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna bite, they're real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you like hamburgers give  'em a try sometime. Me, I can't  usually eat 'em 'cause my girlfriend's  a vegetarian. Which more or less  makes me a vegetarian, but I sure  love the taste of a good burger. (to Brett) You know what they call a Quarter  Pounder with Cheese in France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Oh. Well in that case, will you roll  me one, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he finishes licking it В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have this one, cowgirl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her the rolled smoke. She takes it, putting it t her lips. Out of nowhere appears a Zippo lighter in Vince hand. He lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think nothing of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins rolling one for himself. As this time, the SOUND of a subway car fills the diner,  making everything SHAKE and RATTLE. Marilyn Monroe runs t square vent in the floor. An imaginary subway train BLOWS the skirt of her white dress around her ears as she lets a squeal. The entire restaurant applauds. Back to Mia and Vincent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsellus said you just got back  from Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure did. I heard you did a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was show about a team of female  secret agents called "Fox Force Five."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fox Force Five." Fox, as in we're a  bunch of foxy chicks. Force, as in  we're a force to be reckoned with.  Five, as in there's one... two ...  three... four... five of us. There  was a blonde one, Sommerset O'Neal  from that show "Baton Rouge," she  was the leader. A Japanese one, a  black one, a French one and a brunette  one, me.  We all had special skills.  Sommerset had a photographic memory,  the Japanese fox was a kung fu master,  the black girl was a demolition  expert, the French fox' specialty  was sex...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your specialty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knives. The character I played, Raven  McCoy, her background was she was  raised by circus performers. So she  grew up doing a knife act. According  to the show, she was the deadliest  woman in the world with a knife. But  because she grew up in a circus, she  was also something of an acrobat.  She could do illusions, she was a  trapeze artist В– when you're keeping  the world safe from evil, you never  know when being a trapeze artist's  gonna come in handy. And she knew a  zillion old jokes her grandfather,  an old vaudevillian, taught her. If  we woulda got picked up, they woulda  worked in a gimmick where every  episode I woulda told and ol joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember any of the jokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I only got the chance to say  one, 'cause we only did one show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's really corny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, don't be that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You won't like it and I'll be  embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told it in front of fifty million  people and you can't tell it to me?  I promise I won't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) That's what I'm afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant and you know  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're quite the silver tongue devil,  aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant I wouldn't laugh at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what you said Vince. Well  now I'm definitely not gonna tell  ya, 'cause it's been built up too  much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a gyp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy comes back with the drinks. Mia wraps her lips arou the straw of her shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yummy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a sip of that? I'd like  to know what a five-dollar shake  tastes like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides the shake over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can use my straw, I don't have  kooties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but maybe I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kooties I can handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn! That's a pretty fuckin'  good milk shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if it's worth five  dollars, but it's pretty fuckin'  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides the shake back. Then the first of an uncomfortable silence happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you hate that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncomfortable silences. Why do we  feel it's necessary to yak about  bullshit in order to be comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when you know you found  somebody special. When you can just  shit the fuck up for a minute, and  comfortably share silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we're there yet. But  don't feel bad, we just met each  other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'll tell you what, I'll go to  the bathroom and powder my nose,  while you sit here and think of  something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia powders her nose by doing a big line of coke off the  bathroom sink. Her head jerks up from the rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Steppenwolf) I said goddamn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent digs into his Douglas Sirk steak. As he chews, hi eyes scan the Hellsapopinish restaurant. Mia comes back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you love it when you go to the  bathroom and you come back to find  your food waiting for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're lucky we got it at all. Buddy  Holly doesn't seem to be much of a  waiter. We shoulda sat in Marilyn  Monroe's section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one, there's two Marilyn  Monroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No there's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pointing at Marilyn in the white dress serving a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Marilyn Monroe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, pointing at a BLONDE WAITRESS in a tight sweater an capri pants, taking an order from a bunch of FILM GEEKS В

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that's Mamie Van Doren. I  don't see Jayne Mansfield, so it  must be her night off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did ya think of something to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, there's something I've  wanted to ask you about, but you  seem like a nice person, and I didn't  want to offend you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooohhhh, this doesn't sound like  mindless, boring, getting-to-know- you chit-chat. This sounds like you  actually have something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you promise not to get  offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't promise something like  that. I have no idea what you're  gonna ask. You could ask me what  you're gonna ask me, and my natural  response could be to be offended.  Then, through no fault of my own, I  woulda broken my promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's just forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is an impossibility. Trying to  forget anything as intriguing as  this would be an exercise in futility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia nods her head: "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, it's more exciting when you  don't have permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think about what happened  to Antwan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Antwan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony Rocky Horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell out of a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one way to say it. Another  way is, he was thrown out. Another  was is, he was thrown out by  Marsellus. And even another way is,  he was thrown out of a window by  Marsellus because of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not, it's just what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia and Vincent smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They talk a lot, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They certainly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't by shy Vincent, what  exactly did they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent is slow to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you Bashful, did it  involve the F-word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They just said Rocky Horror gave  you a foot massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No and, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard Marsellus threw Rocky Horror  out of a four-story window because  he massaged my feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you believed that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the time I was told, it seemed  reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marsellus throwing Tony out of a  four story window for giving me a  foot massage seemed reasonable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it seemed excessive. But that  doesn't mean it didn't happen. I  heard Marsellus is very protective  of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A husband being protective of his  wife is one thing. A husband almost  killing another man for touching his  wife's feet is something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing Antwan ever touched  of mine was my hand, when he shook  it. I met Anwan once В– at my wedding  В– then never again.  The truth is,  nobody knows why Marsellus tossed  Tony Rocky Horror out of that window  except Marsellus and Tony Rocky  Horror. But when you scamps get  together, you're worse than a sewing  circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) Ladies and gentlemen, now the moment  you've all been waiting for, the  worldfamous Jackrabbit Slim's twist  contest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrons cheer. Ed Sullivan is with Marilyn Monroe, who holds a trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...One lucky couple will win this  handsome trophy that Marilyn here is  holding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn holds the trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now, who will be our first  contestants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no no, no, no, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping) No, no, no, no, no, no, no. I do  believe Marsellus, my husband, your  boss, told you to take me out and do  whatever I wanted, Now, I want to  dance. I want to win. I want that  trophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, dance good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you asked for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Mia walk onto the dance floor, toward Ed Sull

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) Let's hear it for our first  contestants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrons cheer. Vincent and Mia walk up to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's meet our first contestants  here this evening. Young lady, what  is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) Missus Mia Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) And, uh, how 'bout your fella here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) Vincent Vega.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone) All right, let's see what you can  do. Take it away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia and Vincent dance to Chuck Berry's "YOU NEVER CAN TEL They make hand movements as they dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door FLINGS open, and Mia and Vincent dance tan style into the house, singing a cappella the song from th previous scene. They finish their little dance, laughing. Then... The two just stand face to face looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was than an uncomfortable silence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what that was. (pause) Music and drinks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia moves away to attend to both. Vincent hangs up his  overcoat on a big bronze coat rack in the alcove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna take a piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a little bit more information  than I needed to know, but go right  ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent shuffles off to the john. Mia moves to her CD player, thumbs through a stack of CDs and selects one: k.d. lang. The speakers BLAST OUT a high energy country number, which Mia plays air-guitar to. She dances her way around the room and finds herself by Vince overcoat hanging on the rack. She touches its sleeve. It  feels good. Her hand hoes in its pocket and pulls out his tobacco pou Like a little girl playing cowboy, she spreads the tobacc on some rolling paper. Imitating what he did earlier, lic the paper and rolls it into a pretty good cigarette. Mayb little too fat, but not bad for a first try. Mia thinks s anyway. Her hand reaches back in the pocket and pulls out his Zippo lighter. She SLAPS the lighter against her leg, trying to light it fancy-style like Vince did. What do yo know, she did it! Mia's one happy clam. She triumphantly  brings the fat flame up to her fat smoke, lighting it up, then LOUDLY SNAPS the Zippo closed. The Mia-made cigarette is brought up to her lips, and she takes a long, cool drag. Her hand slides the Zippo back i the overcoat pocket. But wait, her fingers touch somethin else. Those fingers bring out a plastic bag with white po inside, the madman that Vincent bought earlier from Lance Wearing a big smile, Mia brings the bag of heroin up to h face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like you would say  Bingo!) Disco! Vince, you little cola nut,  you've been holding out on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent stands at the sink, washing his hands, talking to himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One drink and leave. Don't be rude,  but drink your drink quickly, say  goodbye, walk out the door, get in  your car, and go down the road.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Mia has the unbeknownst-to-her heroin cut up into big lin on her glass top coffee table. Taking her trusty hundred  dollar bill like a human Dust-Buster, she quickly snorts fat line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her head JERKS back. Her hands go to her nose (which feel like it's on fucking fire), something is terribly wrong.  Then... the rush hits...

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Vincent dries his hands on a towel while he continues his dialogue with the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's a moral test of yourself,  whether or not you can maintain  loyalty. Because when people are  loyal to each other, that's very  meaningful.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Mia is on all fours trying to crawl to the bathroom, but  it's like she's trying to crawl with the bones removed fr her knees. Blood begins to drip from Mia's nose. Then her stomach gets into the act and she VOMITS.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Vince continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're gonna go out there, drink  your drink, say "Goodnight, I've had  a very lovely evening," go home, and  jack off.  And that's all you're  gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that he's given himself a little pep talk, Vincent's  ready for whatever's waiting for him on the other side of that door. So he goes through it.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: We follow behind Vincent as he walks from the bathroom to the living room, where he finds Mia lying on the floor li a rag doll. She's twisted on her back. Blood and puke are down her front. And her face is contorted. Not out of the tightness of pain, but just the opposite, the muscles in face are so relaxed, she lies still with her mouth wide o Slack-jawed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent moves like greased lightning to Mia's fallen body Bending down where she lays, he puts his fingers on her n to check her pulse. She slightly stirs. Mia is aware of Vincent over her, speaking to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sounding weird) Mia! MIA! What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's unable to communicate Mia makes a few lost mumb but they're not distinctive enough to be called words. Vincent props her eyelids open and sees the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) I'll be a son-of-a-bitch. (to Mia) Mia! MIA! What did you take? Answer  me honey, what did you take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia is incapable of answering. He SLAPS her face hard. Vincent SPRINGS up and RUNS to his overcoat, hanging on t rack. He goes through the pockets FRANTICALLY. It's gone. Vince makes a beeline to Mia. We follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to Mia) Okay honey, we're getting you on  your feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches her and hoists the dead weight up in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our feet now, and now we're  gonna talk out to the car. Here we  go, watch us walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow behind as he hurriedly walks the practically- unconscious Mia through the house and out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT SPEEDOMETER: red needle on a hundred. Vincent driving like a madman in a town without traffic l speeds the car into turns and up and over hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent, one hand firmly on the wheel, the other shifting like Robocop, both eyes staring straight ahead except whe he glances over at Mia. Mia, slack-jawed expression, mouth gaping, posture of a b of water. Vincent takes a cellular phone out of his pocket. He punc a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this late hour, LANCE has transformed from a bon vivan drug dealer to a bathrobe creature. He sits in a big comfy chair, ratty blue gym pants, a wor out but comfortable tee-shirt that has, written on it, "T CALIFORNIA", and a moth-ridden terry cloth robe. In his h is a bowl of Cap'n Crunch with Crunch Berries. In front o him on the coffee table is a jug of milk, the box the Cap Crunch with Crunch Berries came out of, and a hash pipe i an ashtray. On the big-screen TV in front of the table is the Three  Stooges, and they're getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) Hold hands, you love birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Lance puts down his cereal and makes his way to the phone It RINGS again. Jody, his wife, CALLS from the bedroom, obviously woken u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance! The phone's ringing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) I can hear it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you told those fuckin'  assholes never to call this late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by the phone) I told 'em and that's what I'm gonna  tell this fuckin' asshole right now! (he answers the phone) Hello, do you know how late it is?  You're not supposed to be callin' me  this fuckin' late.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT IN THE MALIBU
dialogues.text: Vincent is still driving like a stripe-assed ape, clutchi the phone to his ear. WE CUT BACK AND FORTH during the  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, this is Vincent, I'm in big  fuckin' trouble man, I'm on my way  to your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, hold you horses man, what's  the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got an adrenaline shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dawning on him) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need it man, I got a chick she's  fuckin'  Doing on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bring her here!  I'm not even  fuckin' joking with you, don't you  be bringing some fucked up pooh-butt  to my house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's ODin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's dyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then bite the fuckin' bullet, take  'er to a hospital and call a lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't my fuckin' problem, you  fucked her up, you deal with it В–  are you talkin' to me on a cellular  phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you, who is this, don't  come here, I'm hangin' up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late, I'm already here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment inside Lance's house, WE HEAR VINCENT's Ma coming up the street. Lance hangs up the phone, goes to h curtains and YANKS the cord. The curtains open with a WHO in time to see Vincent's Malibu DRIVING UP on his front l and CRASHING into his house. The window Lance is looking of SHATTERS from the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance CHARGES from the window, out the door to his front  lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent is already out of the car, working on getting Mia out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your mind?! You crashed  your car in my fuckin' house! You  talk about drug shit on a cellular  fuckin' phone В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're through havin' your little  hissy fit, this chick is dyin', get  your needle and git it now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you deaf? You're not bringin'  that fucked up bitch in my house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fucked up bitch is Marsellus  Wallace's wife. Now if she fuckin'  croaks on me, I'm a grease spot. But  before he turns me into a bar soap,  I'm gonna be forced to tell 'im about  how you coulda saved her life, but  instead you let her die on your front  lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE START in Lance's and Jody's bedroom. Jody, in bed, throws off the covers and stands up. She's  wearing a long tee-shirt with a picture of Fred Flintston on it. We follow HANDHELD behind her as she opens the door, walk through the hall into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only one-thirty in the goddamn  mornin'! What the fuck's goin' on  out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she walks in the living room, she sees Vincent and Lan standing over Mia, who's lying on the floor in the middle the room. From here on in, everything in this scene is frantic, lik DOCUMENTARY in an emergency ward, with the big difference here being nobody knows what the fuck they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance looks up at Jody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that black box in the bedroom I  have with the adrenaline shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's ODing on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well get her the hell outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in stereo) Get the fuckin' shot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't yell and me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She angrily turns and disappears into the bedroom looking for the shot. WE MOVE into the room with the two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lance) You two are a match made in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, just keep talkin' to her, okay? While she's gettin' the shot, I gotta  get a medical book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need a medical book for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell me how to do it. I've never  given an adrenaline shot before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've had that thing for six years  and you never used it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had to use it. I don't go  joypoppin' with bubble-gummers, all  of my friends can handle their highs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, if you'll let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fuckin' stoppin' you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop talkin' to me, and start talkin'  to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOLLOW Lance as he runs out of the living room into a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bunch of junk in it. He frantically starts scannin the junk for the book he's looking for, repeating the wor "Come on," endlessly. From OFF SCREEN we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up man! We're losin' her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back) I'm looking as fast as I can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance continues his frenzied search. WE HEAR Jody in the living room now as she talks to Vince

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he lookin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, some medical book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody calls to LANCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you lookin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My black medical book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues searching, flipping and knocking over shi Jody appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whata're you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My black fuckin' medical book. It's  like a text book they give to nurses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw a medical book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, I have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if it's that important, why  didn't you keep it with the shot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance spins toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Stop bothering me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you're lookin' for it, that  girl's gonna die on our carpet. You're  never gonna find it in all this shit.   For six months now, I've been telling  you to clean this room В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– get your ass in here, fuck the  book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance angrily knocks over a pile of shit and leaves the S heading for the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Vincent is bent over Mia, talking softly to her, when Lan reenters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit fuckin' around man and give her  the shot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance bends down by the black case brought in by Jody. He opens it and begins preparing the needle for injection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I'm doing this, take her shirt  off and find her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince rips her blouse open. Jody stumbles back in the room, hanging back from the act

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have to be exact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it has to be exact! I'm giving  her an injection in the heart, so I  gotta exactly hit her in the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know exactly where her  heart is, I think it's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vince points to Mia's right breast.  Lance glances over a nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lance readies the injection, Vincent looks up at Jody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a big fat magic marker, got  one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a big fat magic marker, any  felt pen'll do, but a magic marker  would be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody runs to the desk, opens the top drawer and, in her  enthusiasm, she pulls the drawer out of the desk, the con of which (bills, papers, pens) spill to the floor. The injection is ready. Lance hands Vincent the needle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ready, I'll tell you what to  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna give her the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're gonna give her the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never does this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never done this before either,  and I ain't starting now. You brought  'er here, that means you give her  the shot. The day I bring an ODing  bitch to your place, then I gotta  give her the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody hurriedly joins them in the huddle, a big fat red ma marker in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent grabs the magic marker out of Jody's hand and mak a big red dot on Mia's body where her heart is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're giving her an injection  of adrenaline straight to her heart.  But she's got a breast plate in front  of her heart, so you gotta pierce  through that. So what you gotta do  is bring the needle down in a stabbing  motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance demonstrates a stabbing motion, which looks like "T Shape" killing its victims in "HALLOWEEN".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta stab her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want the needle to pierce  through to her heart, you gotta stab  her hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then once you do, push down on the plunger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm curious about that myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't a fuckin' joke man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's supposed to come out of it  like В– (snaps his fingers) В– that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent lifts the needle up above his head in a stabbing  motion. He looks down on Mia. Mia is fading fast. Soon nothing will help her. Vincent's eyes narrow, ready to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count to three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lance, on this knees right beside Vincent, does not know  what to expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED DOT on Mia's body. Needle raised ready to strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody's face is alive with anticipation. NEEDLE in that air, poised like a rattler ready to strike

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The needle leaves frame, THRUSTING down hard. Vincent brings the needle down hard, STABBING Mia in the  chest. Mia's head is JOLTED from the impact. The syringe plunger is pushed down, PUMPING the adrenalin out through the needle. Mia's eyes POP WIDE OPEN and she lets out a HELLISH cry o the banshee. She BOLTS UP in a sitting position, needle s in her chest В– SCREAMING. Vincent, Lance and Jody, who were in sitting positions in front of Mia, JUMP BACK, scared to death. Mia's scream runs out. She slowly starts taking breaths o air. The other three, now scooted halfway across the room, sha to their bones, look to see if she's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're okay, say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia, still breathing, not looking up at them, says in a  relatively normal voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent and Lance collapse on their backs, exhausted and  shaking from how close to death Mia came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody want a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent is behind the wheel driving Mia home. No one says anything, both are still too shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Malibu pulls up to the front. Mia gets out without sa a word (still in a daze) and begins walking down the walk toward her front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around. Vincent's out of the car, standing on the walkway, a big  distance between the two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your thoughts on how to  handle this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm of the opinion that Marsellus  can live his whole live and never  ever hear of this incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. If Marsellus  ever heard of this, I'd be in as  much trouble as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seriously doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can keep a secret, so can I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's shake on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two walk toward each other, holding out their hands t shake and shake they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mum's the word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia lets go of Vincent's hand and silently makes the see- evil, hear-no-evil, and speak-no-evil sign with her hands Vincent smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me, I gotta go home  and have a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia giggles. Vincent turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still wanna hear my "FOX FORCE  FIVE" joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincent turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but I think I'm still a little  too petrified to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. You won't laugh because it's  not funny. But if you still wanna  hear it, I'll tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three tomatoes are walking down the  street, a poppa tomato, a momma  tomato, and a little baby tomato.  The baby tomato is lagging behind  the poppa and momma tomato. The poppa  tomato gets mad, goes over to the  momma tomato and stamps on him В– (stamps on the ground) В– and says: catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both smile, but neither laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya 'round, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia turns and walks inside her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Mia walks inside. Vincent continues to look at wher she was. He brings his hands to his lips and blows her a  kiss. Then exits FRAME leaving it empty. WE HEAR his Mali START UP and DRIVE AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP On the cartoon "SPEED RACER."  Speed is giving a  detailed description of all the features on his race car  "The Mac-5," which he does at the beginning of every epis OFF SCREEN we hear a WOMAN'S VOICE... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the living room of a modest two bedroom house in Alhambra, California, in the year 1972. BUTCH'S MOTHER, 3 stands in the doorway leading into the living room. Next her is a man dressed in the uniform of an American Air Fo officer. The CAMERA is the perspective of a five-year old boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, stop watching TV a second. We  got a special visitor. Now do you  remember when I told you your daddy  dies in a P.O.W. camp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this here is Capt. Koons. He  was in the P.O.W. camp with Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPT. KOONS steps inside the room toward the little boy a bends down on one knee to bring him even with the boy's  eyeline. When Koons speaks, he speaks with a slight Texas accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, little man. Boy I sure heard  a bunch about you. See, I was a good  friend of your Daddy's. We were in  that Hanoi pit of hell over five  years together.  Hopefully, you'll  never have to experience this  yourself, but when two men are in a  situation like me and your Daddy  were, for as long as we were, you  take on certain responsibilities of  the other. If it had been me who had  not made it, Major Coolidge would be  talkin' right now to my son Jim. But  the way it worked out is I'm talkin'  to you, Butch. I got somethin' for  ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain pulls a gold wrist watch out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This watch I got here was first  purchased by your great-granddaddy.  It was bought during the First World  War in a little general store in  Knoxville, Tennessee. It was bought  by private Doughboy Ernie Coolidge  the day he set sail for Paris. It  was your great-granddaddy's war watch,  made by the first company to ever  make wrist watches. You see, up until  then, people just carried pocket  watches. Your great-granddaddy wore  that watch every day he was in the  war. Then when he had done his duty,  he went home to your great- grandmother, took the watch off his  wrist and put it in an ol' coffee  can. And in that can it stayed 'til  your grandfather Dane Coolidge was  called upon by his country to go  overseas and fight the Germans once  again. This time they called it World  War Two. Your great-granddaddy gave  it to your granddad for good luck.   Unfortunately, Dane's luck wasn't as  good as his old man's. Your granddad  was a Marine and he was killed with  all the other Marines at the battle  of Wake Island. Your granddad was  facing death and he knew it. None of  those boys had any illusions about  ever leavin' that island alive. So  three days before the Japanese took  the island, your 22-year old  grandfather asked a gunner on an Air  Force transport named Winocki, a man  he had never met before in his life,  to deliver to his infant son, who he  had never seen in the flesh, his  gold watch. Three days later, your  grandfather was dead. But Winocki  kept his word. After the war was  over, he paid a visit to your  grandmother, delivering to your infant  father, his Dad's gold watch. This  watch. This watch was on your Daddy's  wrist when he was shot down over  Hanoi. He was captured and put in a  Vietnamese prison camp. Now he knew  if the gooks ever saw the watch it'd  be confiscated. The way your Daddy  looked at it, that watch was your  birthright. And he'd be damned if  and slopeheads were gonna put their  greasy yella hands on his boy's  birthright. So he hid it in the one  place he knew he could hide somethin'.  His ass. Five long years, he wore  this watch up his ass. Then when he  died of dysentery, he gave me the  watch. I hid with uncomfortable hunk  of metal up my ass for two years.  Then, after seven years, I was sent  home to my family. And now, little  man, I give the watch to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capt. Koons hands the watch to Butch. A little hand comes into FRAME to accept it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 27-year old Butch Coolidge is dressed in boxing regal trunks, shoes and gloves. He lies on a table catching a f zzzzzz's before his big fight. Almost as soon as WE CUT t him, he wakes up with a start. Shaken by the bizarre memo he wipes his sweaty face with his boxing glove. His trainer KLONDIKE, an older fireplug, opens the door a little, sticking his head in the room. Pandemonium seems be breaking out behind Klondike in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time, Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Klondike steps inside, closing the door on the WILD MOB  outside. He goes to the long yellow robe hanging on a hook. Butch  hops off the table and, without a word, Klondike helps hi on with the robe, which says on the back: "BATTLING BUTCH COOLIDGE". The two men head for the door. Klondike opens the door fo Butch. As Butch steps into the hallway, the Crowd goes apeshit.  Klondike closes the door behind him, leaving us in the qu empty locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear over the black and white title:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– Well Dan, that had to be the  bloodiest and, hands-down, the most  brutal fight this city has ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of chaos in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi is parked in a dark alley next to an auditorium. T sky is PISSIN' DOWN RAIN. WE SLOWLY DOLLY toward the park car. The SOUND of the CAR RADIO can be heard coming from  inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Coolidge was out of there faster  than I've ever seen a victorious  boxer vacate the ring. Do you think  he knew Willis was dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess would be yes, Richard. I  could see from my position here, the  frenzy in his eyes give way to the  realization of what he was doing. I  think any man would've left the ring  that fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the taxi, behind the wheel, is a female cabbie nam ESMARELDA VILLALOBOS. A young woman, with Spanish looks,  sits parked, drinking a steaming hot cup of coffee out of white styrofoam cup. The Sportscasters continue their coverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel this ring death tragedy  will have an effect on the world of  boxing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Dan, a tragedy like this can't  help but shake the world of boxing  to its very foundation. But it's of  paramount importance that during the  sad weeks ahead, the eyes of the  W.B.A. remain firmly fixed on the В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK В– Esmarelda shuts off the radio. She takes a sip of coffee, then hears a NOISE behind her the alley. She sticks her head out of the car door to see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A window about three stories high opens on the auditorium side of the alley. A gym bag is tossed out into a garbage dumpster below the window. Then, Butch Coolidge, still dr in boxing trunks, shoes, gloves and yellow robe, LEAPS to the dumpster below. ESMARELDA'S REACTION takes in the strangeness of this sig Gym bag in hand, Butch CLIMBS out of the dumpster and RUN to the taxi. Before he climbs in, he takes off his robe a throws it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, soaking wet, naked except for trunks, shoes and gl HOPS in the backseat, SLAMMING the door. Esmarelda, staring straight ahead, talks to Butch through the rearview mirror:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish accent) Are you the man I was supposed to  pick up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're the cab I called, I'm the  guy you're supposed to pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ignition key is TWISTED. The engine ROARS to life. The meter is FLIPPED on. Esmarelda's bare foot STOMPS on the gas pedal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab WHIPS out of the alley, FISH-TAILING on the wet  pavement in front of the auditorium at a rapid pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locker room door opens, English Dave fights his way throu the pandemonium which is going on outside in the hall,  shutting the door on the madness. Once inside, English Da takes time to adjust his suit and tie. Mia is standing by the door. She sees Vincent with English Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia. How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I never thanked you for the  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room, black boxer FLOYD RAY WILLIS lies on a table dead. His face looks like he went dunking for bees. His TRAINER on his knees, head on Floyd's chest, crying over the body The huge figure that is Marsellus Wallace stands at the t hand on the Trainer's shoulder, lending emotional support We still do not see Marsellus clearly, only that he is bi Mia sits in a chair at the far end of the room. Marsellus looks up, sees English Dave and walks over to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'cha got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He booked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm prepared to scour the earth for  this motherfucker. If Butch goes to  Indo China, I want a nigger hidin'  in a bowl of rice, ready to pop a  cap in his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch gets one of his boxing gloves off. Esmeralda watches in the rearview mirror. He tries to roll down one of the backseat windows, but ca find the roll bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how do I open the window back  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She presses a button and the back window moves down. Butc tosses his boxing glove out the window, then starts untyi the other one. Esmeralda can't keep quiet anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still working on the  glove) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in that fight? The fight on  the radio В– you're the fighter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he tosses his other glove out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever gave you that idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No c'mon, you're him, I know you're  him, tell me you're him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drying himself with  a gym towel) I'm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed the other boxing man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio said he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finished wiping himself down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Sorry 'bout that, Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the towel out the window. Silence, as Butch digs in his bag for a t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it feel like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finds his shirt) What does what feel like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killing a man. Beating another man  to death with your bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch pulls on his tee-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you some kinda weirdo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's a subject I have much  interest in. You are the first person  I ever met who has killed somebody.  So, what was it like to kill a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell ya what, you give me one of  them cigarettes, I'll give you an  answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esmarelda bounces in her seat with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch leans forward. Esmarelda, keeping her eyes on the r passes a cigarette back to him. He takes it. Then, still looking behind her, she brings up her hand, a lit match i it. Butch lights his smoke, then blows out the match. He takes a long drag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Esmarelda Villalobos В– is that  Mexican?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Spanish, but I'm  Columbian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a very pretty name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It mean "Esmarelda of the wolves."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one hell of a name you got  there, sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. And what is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch. What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an American, our names don't  mean shit. Anyway, moving right along,  what is it you wanna know, Esmarelda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know what it feels like to  kill a man В–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В– I couldn't tell ya. I didn't know  he was dead 'til you told me he was  dead. Now I know he's dead, do you  wanna know how I feel about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esmarelda nods her head: "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel the least little bit  bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We DOLLY around a phone booth as Butch talks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) What'd I tell ya, soon as the word  got out a fix was in, the odds would  be outta control. Hey, if he was a  better fighter he's be alive. If he  never laced up his gloves in the  first place, which he never shoulda  done, he'd be alive. Enough about  the poor unfortunate Mr. Floyd, let's  talk about the rich and prosperous  Mr. Butch.  How many bookies you  spread it around with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight? How long to collect? (pause) So by tomorrow evening, you'll have  it all? (pause) Good news Scotty, real good news В– I  understand a few stragglers aside.  Me an'  Fabienne're gonna leave in  the morning. It should take us a  couple days to get into Knoxville.  Next time we see each other, it'll  be on Tennessee time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch hangs up the phone. He looks at the cab waiting to  take him wherever he wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself in French  with English subtitles) Fabienne my love, our adventure  begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esmeralda's taxi pulled into the motel parking lot. The r has stopped, but the night is still soaked. Butch gets ou now fully dressed in tee-shirt, jeans and high school ath jacket. He leans in the driver's side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handing her the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
